paper.title: Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b

core_question: Does TRAPPIST-1 b, an Earth-sized rocky planet orbiting an M dwarf, retain any atmosphere under strong stellar irradiation?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Observed system
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: one rocky exoplanet with phase-resolved thermal spectra
datasets_or_cohorts.description: TRAPPIST-1 b, an Earth-sized rocky planet on a very short, likely tidally locked orbit around an M dwarf, observed with JWST MIRI phase-curve spectroscopy.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Null scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: bare-rock model with minimal heat redistribution
datasets_or_cohorts.description: A bare-rock, no-atmosphere model representing the null hypothesis with minimal heat redistribution, used as a comparator for atmospheric detection.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: CO2-rich atmosphere scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: An atmosphere-bearing model with significant greenhouse gas absorption, particularly CO2, used to test for atmospheric signatures in thermal emission.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: O2-rich atmosphere scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: An oxidized composition model with weaker CO2 signature constraints, representing alternative atmospheric compositions not fully ruled out by current data.

major_limitations: This is a single-planet study and does not establish atmospheric prevalence across all M-dwarf rocky planets.
Retrieval assumptions (circulation, opacity priors, cloud treatment) affect quantitative posteriors.
Stellar variability and instrument systematics can bias weak spectral features.
Night-side constraints are weaker than day-side constraints in the current dataset.
Degeneracies between composition, clouds/hazes, and circulation assumptions remain significant.
